pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

content.raw:
Took a whack at just scripting out what’s necessary for encoding that diagram, but ran into redundancy:

```xml
<model name="joint_frames">
  <link name="parent">
    <pose>{X_MP}</pose>
    <frame name="j1">
      <pose>{X_PJp}</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>
  <link name="child">
    <!-- REDUNDANCY: X_JcC and X_CJc are inverse / reptitions... -->
    <pose frame="parent/j1">{X_JcC}</pose>
    <frame name="j1">
      <pose>{X_CJc}</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <pose frame="child/j1"/>
    <parent>parent</parent>
    <child>child</child>
  </joint>
</model>
```

While we can certainly adjust the origin of `child` s.t. `X_CJc` is identity \(a la URDF\), that feels dirty…

Given the current proposal, is there a way to remove this redundancy, and permit `//link[@name=”child”]/pose` to not be driven by just one of it’s connecting joints?

EDIT: I guess this can be alleviated by either not specifying `child/j1`, and just letting the joint pose be specified w.r.t. `parent/j1`:

```
...
  <link name="child">
    <pose frame="parent/j1">{X_JcC}</pose>
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <pose frame="parent/j1"/>
    <parent>parent</parent>
    <child>child</child>
  </joint>
...
```

Caveat is that now users cannot find out what `child/j1` actually is unless they add redundant information… 

If, in this proposal, we define that the implicit frame `joint1` is physically attached to the child link, then everything more-or-less can make sense and be referable?

As an alternative, there could be an implicit frame added, e.g. `child/joint1`, and then users can name things s.t. they can then see `parent/joint1` and `child/joint1` and everything is physically meaningful with maximal coordinates.
content.html:
Took a whack at just scripting out what’s necessary for encoding that diagram, but ran into redundancy:

<model name="joint_frames">
  <link name="parent">
    <pose>{X_MP}</pose>
    <frame name="j1">
      <pose>{X_PJp}</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>
  <link name="child">
    <!-- REDUNDANCY: X_JcC and X_CJc are inverse / reptitions... -->
    <pose frame="parent/j1">{X_JcC}</pose>
    <frame name="j1">
      <pose>{X_CJc}</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <pose frame="child/j1"/>
    <parent>parent</parent>
    <child>child</child>
  </joint>
</model>

While we can certainly adjust the origin of child s.t. X_CJc is identity (a la URDF), that feels dirty…

Given the current proposal, is there a way to remove this redundancy, and permit //link[@name=”child”]/pose to not be driven by just one of it’s connecting joints?

EDIT: I guess this can be alleviated by either not specifying child/j1, and just letting the joint pose be specified w.r.t. parent/j1:

...
  <link name="child">
    <pose frame="parent/j1">{X_JcC}</pose>
  </link>
  <joint name="joint1">
    <pose frame="parent/j1"/>
    <parent>parent</parent>
    <child>child</child>
  </joint>
...

Caveat is that now users cannot find out what child/j1 actually is unless they add redundant information…

If, in this proposal, we define that the implicit frame joint1 is physically attached to the child link, then everything more-or-less can make sense and be referable?

As an alternative, there could be an implicit frame added, e.g. child/joint1, and then users can name things s.t. they can then see parent/joint1 and child/joint1 and everything is physically meaningful with maximal coordinates.

content.raw:
Per f2f, we should aim towards codifying \(in XML\) this diagram, using these specified frames:  
[https://gist.github.com/amcastro-tri/bc9aabb90a44e21e60773527b06fdea5](https://gist.github.com/amcastro-tri/bc9aabb90a44e21e60773527b06fdea5)

content.raw:
```xml
<include file="mug" child_frame="mug/buttom_center">
  <pose frame="table/top_center">0 0 0  0 0 0</pose>
</include>
---
<include file="mug">
  <pose frame="table/top_center">0 0 0  0 0 0</pose>
  <child_frame>mug/buttom_center</child_frame>
</include>
```
content.html:
<include file="mug" child_frame="mug/buttom_center">
  <pose frame="table/top_center">0 0 0  0 0 0</pose>
</include>
---
<include file="mug">
  <pose frame="table/top_center">0 0 0  0 0 0</pose>
  <child_frame>mug/buttom_center</child_frame>
</include>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

content.raw:
a compromise proposal, allow include tags to place objects such that frames coincide:

~~~
<include file="table"/>

<include file="mug">
  <parent_frame>table/top_center</parent_frame>
  <child_frame>mug/bottom_center</child_frame>
</include>
~~~
content.html:
a compromise proposal, allow include tags to place objects such that frames coincide:

<include file="table"/>

<include file="mug">
  <parent_frame>table/top_center</parent_frame>
  <child_frame>mug/bottom_center</child_frame>
</include>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

content.raw:
Some other high-level notes:

* Handling data redundancy: Coincident frame style necessitates discarding parent and/or child link poses \(possibly\)
* Physical-ness: Force-pose style, with screw-style joints, requires a bit of a mental jump \(for me\) to posit on what the kinematics are
content.html:
Some other high-level notes:

  • Handling data redundancy: Coincident frame style necessitates discarding parent and/or child link poses (possibly)
  • Physical-ness: Force-pose style, with screw-style joints, requires a bit of a mental jump (for me) to posit on what the kinematics are

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

content.raw:
We also spoke about how scoping works; one possibility is to only permit one direction of referencing \(parent element to child element\)

E.g.:

* `<model/>` can specify frames, can refer to frames defined inside of `<link/>` tags
* `<link/>` can specify frames, but can only refer to frames defined inside of itself
* `<joint><pose/></joint>` may or may not be able to define frames \(depending on how spec shakes out\)
content.html:
We also spoke about how scoping works; one possibility is to only permit one direction of referencing (parent element to child element)

E.g.:

  • <model/> can specify frames, can refer to frames defined inside of <link/> tags
  • <link/> can specify frames, but can only refer to frames defined inside of itself
  • <joint><pose/></joint> may or may not be able to define frames (depending on how spec shakes out)

content.raw:
For force-pose style, we also talked about the explicit call-out of canonical model links; could possibly also do explicit call out based on frame, to permit “abstraction” of sorts:

```xml
<frame name="canonical">
    <pose frame="my_base_link">0 0 1  0 0 0</pose>
</frame>
```
content.html:
For force-pose style, we also talked about the explicit call-out of canonical model links; could possibly also do explicit call out based on frame, to permit “abstraction” of sorts:

<frame name="canonical">
    <pose frame="my_base_link">0 0 1  0 0 0</pose>
</frame>

content.raw:
Sorry for the delay; scribbles from VC meeting:

Force-pose style:

```xml
<include file="table">
    <force_pose frame="my_base_link">
        <pose frame="world">...</pose>
    </force_pose>
</include>

<include file="mug">
  <pose frame="table/top_center"></pose>
</include>

<joint type="fixed">
    <parent>table</parent>
    <child>mug</child>
</joint>
```

‌

Coincident frame style: \(what we use in Anzu model directives\)

```xml
<include file="table">
</include>

<frame name="table_origin">
    <pose frame="world">0 1.5 0  0 0 0</pose>
</frame>

<joint type="fixed" force_coincidence="false">
    <parent>table_origin</parent>
    <!-- <child>table/bottom_center</child> -->
    <child>table/bottom_left_leg</child>
</joint>

<include file="mug"/>

<joint type="fixed">
    <parent>table/top_center</parent>
    <child>mug/bottom_center</child>
</joint>
```
content.html:
Sorry for the delay; scribbles from VC meeting:

Force-pose style:

<include file="table">
    <force_pose frame="my_base_link">
        <pose frame="world">...</pose>
    </force_pose>
</include>

<include file="mug">
  <pose frame="table/top_center"></pose>
</include>

<joint type="fixed">
    <parent>table</parent>
    <child>mug</child>
</joint>

‌

Coincident frame style: (what we use in Anzu model directives)

<include file="table">
</include>

<frame name="table_origin">
    <pose frame="world">0 1.5 0  0 0 0</pose>
</frame>

<joint type="fixed" force_coincidence="false">
    <parent>table_origin</parent>
    <!-- <child>table/bottom_center</child> -->
    <child>table/bottom_left_leg</child>
</joint>

<include file="mug"/>

<joint type="fixed">
    <parent>table/top_center</parent>
    <child>mug/bottom_center</child>
</joint>

content.raw:
Per f2f, we should figure out whether or not `parent` and `child` can be swapped, e.g. if adding a model for a rotor \+ stator, this may be necessary.

Interestingly enough, a topic along this vein came up on Drake Slack: [https://drakedevelopers.slack.com/archives/C2WBPQDB7/p1554935336019900](https://drakedevelopers.slack.com/archives/C2WBPQDB7/p1554935336019900)

If that's the case, do we want to reconsider the name `parent` and `child`? Drake generalizes this by specifying `inboard` and `outboard`…
content.html:
Per f2f, we should figure out whether or not parent and child can be swapped, e.g. if adding a model for a rotor + stator, this may be necessary.

Interestingly enough, a topic along this vein came up on Drake Slack: https://drakedevelopers.slack.com/archives/C2WBPQDB7/p1554935336019900

If that's the case, do we want to reconsider the name parent and child? Drake generalizes this by specifying inboard and outboard…

content.raw:
Per f2f, we may want to avoid adding poses to joints which weld links, and instead have joints weld frames. With this, users can specify offsets however they care.

Adding a task to that effect.
content.html:
Per f2f, we may want to avoid adding poses to joints which weld links, and instead have joints weld frames. With this, users can specify offsets however they care.

Adding a task to that effect.

content.raw:
What would this be interpreted as when parsed in C\+\+?

Is it equal to `const char* str = "\\/";` in this case?

EDIT: Just to make sure, `\` doesn’t have a reserved purpose in XML attribute strings, does it?

EDIT 2: Ah, yup, `\` is not reserved: [https://stackoverflow.com/a/539158/7829525](https://stackoverflow.com/a/539158/7829525)
content.html:
What would this be interpreted as when parsed in C++?

Is it equal to const char* str = "\\/"; in this case?

EDIT: Just to make sure, \ doesn’t have a reserved purpose in XML attribute strings, does it?

EDIT 2: Ah, yup, \ is not reserved: https://stackoverflow.com/a/539158/7829525

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: proposal for new behavior

content.raw:
Not a strong opinion, but we could also do this the other way around, where slashes are escaped when the name is created instead of when the name is used to refer to something. So `/` is reserved in all `name` attributes and during URDF->SDF conversion `/`s become `\/`. And this example would then look like:
```
<model name="embedded_link_frame_escaping">
  <link name="name\/with\\slashes">
    <frame name="frame1">
      <pose>0.5 0.2 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>

  <link name="unescaped_link_frame">
    <pose frame="name/with\slashes/frame1"/> <!-- INVALID: implies search for name -> with\slashes -> frame1 -->
  </link>

  <link name="escaped_link_frame">
    <pose frame="name\/with\\slashes/frame1"/> <!-- VALID. -->
  </link>
</model>
```

The advantage is the link name `name\/with\\slashes` is used as is in pose frame attribute. This would also be the case when creating a joint.

```
<joint name="j1">
  <parent>some_link</parent>
  <child>name\/with\\slashes</child>
</joint>
```
In both cases,  it might be less confusing to use the link name directly without having to escape it since it's already escaped.
content.html:
Not a strong opinion, but we could also do this the other way around, where slashes are escaped when the name is created instead of when the name is used to refer to something. So / is reserved in all name attributes and during URDF->SDF conversion /s become \/. And this example would then look like:

<model name="embedded_link_frame_escaping">
  <link name="name\/with\\slashes">
    <frame name="frame1">
      <pose>0.5 0.2 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
  </link>

  <link name="unescaped_link_frame">
    <pose frame="name/with\slashes/frame1"/> <!-- INVALID: implies search for name -> with\slashes -> frame1 -->
  </link>

  <link name="escaped_link_frame">
    <pose frame="name\/with\\slashes/frame1"/> <!-- VALID. -->
  </link>
</model>

The advantage is the link name name\/with\\slashes is used as is in pose frame attribute. This would also be the case when creating a joint.

<joint name="j1">
  <parent>some_link</parent>
  <child>name\/with\\slashes</child>
</joint>

In both cases, it might be less confusing to use the link name directly without having to escape it since it's already escaped.
